lord tammerlain

http://www.theautochannel.com/news/2005/11/18/148526.html
 
 The end is near for GM, Ford.
 
 

 DETROIT, Nov 18, 2005; Reuters reported that Toyota Motor Corp. grabbed more U.S. retail market share than Ford Motor Co. in early November and it was less than one share point behind General Motors Corp., J.D. Power and Associates said on Friday.
 
 snip
 
 GM and Ford both reported 23 percent declines in their U.S. sales last month, as high gasoline prices hurt demand for their big sport utility vehicles and industrywide sales fell to their slowest pace in seven years.
 
 DaimlerChrysler was in fourth place in early November, with a retail share of 13.6 percent, while Honda Motor Co. Ltd. (7267.T: Quote, Profile, Research) took the No. 5 spot with a 12.2 percent share.
 
 Nissan Motor Co. Ltd., which suffered a 13 percent decline in October sales, appears to be in line for more disappointing results in November, according to the Power Information Network. It said Nissan's retail sales were down 15 percent from the same period last year and its share was holding flat at 7.8 percent.

 Contrary to popular belief, Chrysler was not in long term danger of going under. Chrysler's problem was a cash flow problem. Their sales were still reasonable, and there was great potential in the company. As an accountant, you should understand the impact that a poor cash management strategy can have.
 
 American automakers problem now is that they are simply uncompetitive. This is not a cash flow problem that can be solved with a bailout. The entire industry is shot. American automakers have a reputation for poor quality. Their product lines do not meet the demands of the modern consumer, and their legacy costs are outrageous, which quite frankly is their own damn fault.
 
 The simple fact of the matter is American automakers have been mismanaged for so many years that they are self destructing.

 Unless there has been a massive shift from accrual to cash based accounting taht I am unaware of, I would think that having accountants with at least a basic understanding of cash management would be pretty important. Is sucha shift in basic paradigm has not taken place, it would seem to me that an accoutnant who is concerned only with the past would be searching for a job in short order, since accounts payable are just as important as accounts due (since they are essentially already on the books), and it is that little hole in between which is truly important. 
 
 Unless, of course, you are just a tax accountant, in which case the past is all that matters.

 All of those proposed job cuts are under current union agreements, which provide five years of pay/benefits(?) after termination. No union membership will ever give up that degree of wages (and dues), especially when they know the jobs are gone, and those negotiations are yet to come. 
 
 While hourly wage job cuts will be equivalent to 27% of that 111,000 labor force, the announcement stated 7% of 35,000 salaried workers will be cut. Is my math poor or is there something wrong with that ratio? 
 
 I see little tangible benefit to GM in the announcement. It appears to be a publicity effort to slow loss of equity investment and resulting revolving debt ratio imbalance, technical default.

 Oh, and finanacial analyists are more interested in cash flow then the accountant :p

 
 Every treasury department, including GM, is staffed by bean counters. Financial reporting provides the numbers for treasury to crunch. Simplified, financial analyst is a bean counter highly skilled in spreadsheet construction and modeling who provides 'what if' scenarios, allowing the CFO to pick from what he/she thinks bank/brokerage 'analysts' will swallow without choking. Cash flow dominates both financial reporting, where AP disburses payments or holds them, and treasury, who determines what payments will be made dependent on cash flow. Lowly AP disbursement clerks generally know when a company has cash flow problems before the CEO.

 I haven't been involved in a few years, but we used recent grads in treasury analysis because they generally had the best software expertise and didn't question motive. I agree with finance people (the treasury side) having better career paths than financial reporting, primarily because practical experience outside of financial reporting is required to develop expertise in finance and that involves interaction with the outside world. Accountants in financial reporting are not unlike some engineers when it comes to isolation.

GM's 'restructuring' announcement fell flat on its face in the investment world. S&P announced another reduction in GM's bond rating, the stock dropped 2% and UAW says they'll fight them tooth and nail. 
 
 Same comments; historical corporate culture is still intact, legacy costs won't be affected, poor model mix, $1-2-billion restructuring charge for no gain until 2008, the big one - no forecast of lost revenue from the restructure and etc., etc., etc. 
 
 Amazingly enough, I took a look at GM's 'blog', and Lutz is still championing SUVs! Talk about being stuck in a timewarp.

 It does take blind faith, or desperation, to tout a new model directed at a market segment that's in serious decline for reasons far more basic than styling. IMO, that's a prime indication of GM's antiquated corporate culture of 'knowing' what's best for the consumer without having a clue. That arrogance has been a major contributor to their decline and it seems to be alive and well.
Alan Ryan

All of those proposed job cuts are under current union agreements, which provide five years of pay/benefits(?) after termination. No union membership will ever give up that degree of wages (and dues), especially when they know the jobs are gone, and those negotiations are yet to come. 
 

 Is this the "jobs bank" into which GM transfers redundant employees ? I assume they stay on the books as "ghost workers" waiting for an upturn in the business - at which point they can return to life and a full time job ? Meantime, they collect their salaries, health benefits, etc. 
 
 If there is no upturn for GM - which seems virtually certain - 5 years seems a long time for the company to support this deadweight. And I thought American capitalism was synonymous with ruthless and unsentimental realism !
georged

Is this the "jobs bank" into which GM transfers redundant employees ? I assume they stay on the books as "ghost workers" waiting for an upturn in the business - at which point they can return to life and a full time job ? Meantime, they collect their salaries, health benefits, etc. 
 
 If there is no upturn for GM - which seems virtually certain - 5 years seems a long time for the company to support this deadweight. And I thought American capitalism was synonymous with ruthless and unsentimental realism !

 
 I'm not familiar with the exact details of GM's labor contracts, but do know union workers terminated for plant closings, efficiency, etc. are guaranteed existing income/benefits for a number of years. Perhaps someone can clarify that.
 
 GM's historic corporate philosophy and subsequent culture has been based on a paternal image; keep your nose clean, don't make waves, get a good rabbi and you'll have a job for life with regular promotions. Unfortunately, that image doesn't integrate employee input, individual thinking contributing to positive forward movement, and encourages mediocrity from yes people. Fine when absolute control over domestic markets was a fact, tell the public what they need and they'll never know the difference, but global competition has eaten that culture alive and GM has failed, or refused, to see the light. Reasonable and innovative change, I do like ruthlessness and realism, are required by individuals and business entities to achieve positive growth. 
 
 The ripple effects from GM's decline will, hopefully, help shake the American public out of their lethargic mindset of being 'owed' jobs regardless of performance levels. Far too many Americans and American companies are still mentally in 1965 economic and moral positions, refusing to accept 40-years of change. Harsh medicine, but it often takes that to instill necessary change.
Alan Ryan

 Yesterday's announcement was GM's call to reality directed towards the UAW.
 The most significant changes being addressed are legacy cost reductions - $15Billion; reduced healthcare benefits for current UAW employees- $3Billion/year and a reduction in plant capacity by 1 Million units/year by closing or reducing shifts at 6 plants. That will eliminate 30,000 more jobs and save $7Billion/year IIRC.
 With the recent "GM Employee Pricing" for all car buyers, GM showed that when they sell their vehicles at prices comparable to the imports (who don't have the high employee/legacy costs) they can compete with imports. They certainly have better designed products than ancient Toyota (Camry) and Honda (Civic) models that finally got facelifts as their sales started to drop off. 
 On a level playing field, I'll take the American made car every time.
Alan Ryan

 As I posted, the investment community is giving no credibility to GM's announced restructure for several very important reasons:
 
 1. No revenue forecast with $1-2 billion restructuring charges
 2. No market share forecast with reduced production capability
 3. Duplicated models
 4. No restructuring of the corporate culture
 5. How they'll cope with existing legacy costs without shedding them through formal reorganization
 
 At this point I don't think quality is even an issue in the overall picture; past poor quality left a bad impression on the public that will take a couple of generations to overcome.
Alan Ryan

Even employees don't buy cars at "cost". There's always a built-in profit margin, albeit a small one.

 Rover, the British car manufacturer, had a scheme for selling cars to their employees at near cost prices. Many of these sales were also financed by a cheap company loan. In effect, Rover loaned money to employees who wanted to buy a car from them at a subsidised price. Not good business practice: the company went into liquidation earlier this year. 
 
 Selling cars at a very low profit to their employees did not of course (by itself) ruin Rover. It's a complicated story but we can boil it down to its failure to update its models, and make attractive cars that people wanted to buy at a competitive price.
billsco

I was most interested in GM's announcements in regard to their now-failed experiment: Saturn. This was suppose to be a stand-alone company able to compete head on with the Japanese in what is regarded as the entry-level market. The manufacturing plant building these in Tennessee is one of announced closings. Thus it's dead in the water, IMO, though the name might live on.
 
 Saturn marketed itself as providing outstanding service. I remember my wife Joyce wanting to buy one of these vehicles after being impressed with the TV ads. I recall arguing that if a car company makes a quality product, service should not be much of a consideration, at least not the primary one. We argued on and off, I recall, and often puzzled over GM's strategy and Saturn's appeal to some.
 
 And so it turned out to be nothing but another GM product with all the attendant problems of the company. It never did stand alone.
georged

Saturn actually died in 2000 when GM decided to take sales, service and marketing into the corporate fold; marketing being the driving force behind any consumer product. There was no way an 'independent' model such as Saturn could survive while competing for resources in GM's inbred fiefdom system.
